content_parts.text: —Traditionally the prophet Joel (commemorated October 19), son of Pethuel, of the tribe of Reuben.
His is a common Jewish name, meaning “Yahweh is God.” Nothing is known of his life outside of his short prophecy.
—Any number of dates have been suggested for Joel's life.
Jerome and Isidore place Joel in the time of the prophets Isaiah and Hosea, about 740 BC.
Tradition held Joel to be one of the earlier prophets; modern scholars are undecided about the matter, often placing him at about 450–400 BC, after the restoration of Israel from exile.
(1) A call summoning the people of God to turn their sorrow into penitence (
(2) The faithfulness of God to rise up on behalf of His people, restore their prosperity, and bring the nations to justice (
(3) The coming of the Holy Spirit, the Third Person of the Trinity (
Joel emphasizes the universal mission of the Spirit, anticipating the Day of Pentecost, when He is poured out on all flesh.
—It is likely the prophet Joel wrote in the face of a double disaster—the attack of military aggressors such as the Babylonians, and the onset of a plague of locusts.
The prophet freely switches between the two calamities, likening them to each other.
As the narrative proceeds, Joel employs two distinct prophetic genres: (1) he calls his people to contrition and repentance; and (2) he uses vivid apocalyptic imagery to convey deep spiritual truths.
The contrast created by these two approaches prompted St.
Jerome to comment, “Joel is clear at the beginning, but at the end more obscure.”
